content.html:
@elly Yeah, that all makes sense. My gut reaction is that the web platform should provide a single solution that‚Äôs consistent enough across browsers and addresses accessibility issues.
But, even if that happens, it doesn‚Äôt sound like it would be ideal for every circumstance (thinking specifically about Adrian‚Äôs article and the examples they gave).

content.html: @patrick_h_lauke @elly @hi_mayank I don‚Äôt see how you can blame people for using W3C official spec, clearly designed to be more explicit than the general input types already available. At *worst* they fall back to the old behaviour in non-supporting browsers. The en-shittification is in how the implementors implemented the spec, and made it worse than not supporting it at all.

content.html:
@mattwilcox @elly @hi_mayank blame lies often quite squarely with browser devs who implement the latest shiny things, but without regard for accessibility. or rather, their QA processes...how can you let inaccessible UI widgets just go to production? and then a special F.U. to Dragon https://mastodon.social/@patrick_h_lauke/109980970204824602

content.html:
@elly It really is disheartening how many "modern" input types have been at best a total waste of time for all involved, and at worst making life harder for everyone instead of better. It's bizarre.

@hi_mayank
content.text: @elly It really is disheartening how many "modern" input types have been at best a total waste of time for all involved, and at worst making life harder for everyone instead of better. It's bizarre.@hi_mayank

content.html:
@joshfreedman There's a lot of reasons.
The date picker pattern is a very complex one, which often confuses users even when it's done right.
And the way that it's implemented differs greatly from platform to platform, as well as all the custom implementations. Users can't get used to one implementation.
Then on top of that there are lots of accessibility issues with many implementations.
content.text:
@joshfreedman There's a lot of reasons.
The date picker pattern is a very complex one, which often confuses users even when it's done right.
And the way that it's implemented differs greatly from platform to platform, as well as all the custom implementations. Users can't get used to one implementation.
Then on top of that there are lots of accessibility issues with many implementations.

there was also react-aria's datepicker recently (https://react-spectrum.adobe.com/blog/date-and-time-pickers-for-all.html) but iirc it was too verbose and not tested with real users

i really wish the platform would give us more accessible defaults here

content.html:
@elly The social images use CSS Houdini APIs that involved running Puppeteer with a flag to enable experimental web platform features, so I wanted to keep things as simple as possible

You can see how the build process works by looking at the tasks labelled `screenshots:`
https://github.com/LondonCSS/website/blob/main/package.json

website/package.json at main ¬∑ LondonCSS/website

@elly For https://www.londoncss.dev I also didn‚Äôt want to deal with Lambdas, so I made it part of the build process. Nothing fancy, but easy to maintain at least!

Event 6: Creative CSS

children.name: Unable to find a post about a CSS reset

content.html:
I have searched my browsers (both home & work) bookmarks and history‚ÄîNothing.

Evernote. My blog. My email. My code repo. Still nothing.

I read a post concerning a new CSS reset/baseline. I liked it's approach and cribbed some of it for this blog.

It contained adding the default system fonts to the body tag.


font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, Segoe UI, Roboto, Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif, Apple Color Emoji, Segoe UI Emoji;
/* Only supported on Chromium-based browsers and Safari */
font-family: system-ui;"

Also had adding word-wrap, etc., to the p element...

	
word-wrap: break-word;
overflow-wrap: break-word;
hyphens: auto;
max-width: 80ch;

...as well as adding color-scheme to the root

	
:root {
		color-scheme: light dark;
	}

By the end of Saturday I had so many tabs open, but none of them were it.

It is not Zell Liew's CSS reset, Andy Bell's modern CSS reset, or Josh Comeau's custom CSS reset.

Elly Loel's modern CSS reset came close, but no cigar.

All the above have elements of it, and due to the collaborative nature of the web, build on each other, so I don't know if I'm mis-remembering and making a composite in my brain or what.

I do know the post was about creating something "mobile-first", light, and user-centric.

Until I find it (if ever) these are all good resources that I have now bookmarked, and posted here.

@elly (boosting for the nice summary, not for the fact that I agree with you about mandatory &)

(Ok, ok, boosting because both)
content.text: @elly (boosting for the nice summary, not for the fact that I agree with you about mandatory &)(Ok, ok, boosting because both)

content.html: @AmeliaBR ü§≠‚ù§Ô∏è hahah great minds think alike
content.text: @AmeliaBR ü§≠‚ù§Ô∏è hahah great minds think alike

content.html:
@elly Great overview! The counter-arguments on required `&`:

1. It doesn't fix all the edge-cases - you still need :is() sometimes - so not a huge technical win. Otherwise this would have sold it.

2. When copy/pasting complex selectors, it's easy to miss an `&` that needs added or removed. But we know what you meant. Why break parsing over it?

3. When we poll author preferences, they're 50/50. Those who want it can lint. Everyone wins?

But you're not alone, it's a common request.
content.text: @elly Great overview! The counter-arguments on required `&`: 1. It doesn't fix all the edge-cases - you still need :is() sometimes - so not a huge technical win. Otherwise this would have sold it.2. When copy/pasting complex selectors, it's easy to miss an `&` that needs added or removed. But we know what you meant. Why break parsing over it?3. When we poll author preferences, they're 50/50. Those who want it can lint. Everyone wins?But you're not alone, it's a common request.
